clinical_study.brief_title: Feasibility in Every Day Pratice in an ENT Department and Value of the Automatic Detection of Respiratory Events
clinical_study.official_title: Respiratory Polygraphy in Children : Feasibility in Every Day Pratice in an ENT Department and Value of the Automatic Detection of Respiratory Events

brief_summary.textblock: The use of respiratory polygraphy (RP) in children for the diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea hypopnea syndrome (OSAHS) can be challenging: device acceptance, sensors displacement. The automatic analysis of respiratory events has never been evaluated in a pediatric population. The primary objective of this study was to determine the feasibility of pediatric RP in an ENT department routine practice. The second objective was to evaluate the reliability of the automatic signal analysis in children.

detailed_description.textblock: Retrospective single center study of 50 children (32 boys and 18 girls, mean age 5.5 Â± 2.3 years) who benefited from an overnight RP in an ENT hospitalization department between January and August 2016 for OSAS suspicion. Manual detection of respiratory events was performed by the same ENT specialist, and compared to the automatic analysis.

primary_outcome.measure: Overall signal quality of the respiratory polygraph
primary_outcome.description: retrospective data collection : Overall signal quality of RP (Respiratory polygraphy)

study_pop.textblock: Children with clinical obstructive sleep apnea hypopnea syndrome in University Health Center

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria:
- Age between 2 and 12 years
- child having performed a ventilatory polygraph for suspicion of obstructive hypopnoea apnea syndrome
Exclusion criteria:
- over 12 years old
